title: I find them on the street & shadow.
partialText: It wasn’t until the end of our chat that I learned her name.

title: Our frail thoughts.
partialText: I should be writing about a terrifically difficult year. Instead, I’m thinking about flowers and dead men.

title: The line and the stream.
partialText: “Artificial intelligence is the future,” they tell me. The thing is, futures are tricky.

title: A right to copy.
partialText: This is one author’s short, failed journey to file a claim in Anthropic’s copyright lawsuit. (Oops. Spoilers, sorry.)

title: A carried leaf.
partialText: What we talk about when we talk about showing our work.

title: Some well-made things.
partialText: Here are some things I’ve enjoyed lately.

title: Against the protection of stocking frames.
partialText: “Artificial intelligence” is a failed technology. It’s time we described it that way.

title: A notional design studio.
partialText: A design language, if you can keep it.

title: Newslettered.
partialText: Eric wrote about his newsletter subscriptions, and asked some friends to do the same. Here’s my entry.

title: Link bug.
partialText: I added a links section to my website. Here’s how I made it, and why.

title: Unbreaking.
partialText: Here’s to new work, and to a little more clarity amid the chaos.

title: Responsive web design turns fifteen.
partialText: The original “Responsive Web Design” article was published fifteen years ago. Time’s weird, man.

title: Hallucinating.
partialText: A minor semantic quibble.

title: Magick images.
partialText: I’ve upgraded my site’s social media preview images, using a combination of ImageMagick and Eleventy. Here’s entirely too many words about how I made it all happen.

title: It’s time to organize.
partialText: There’s an old organizing joke someone once told me: “Who’s in the union? You and I.”

title: You deserve a new book design.
partialText: A peek into You Deserve a Tech Union’s new design, and the typefaces—and process—that made it happen.

title: Refresh.
partialText: In 2023, I wrote a book. Several months later, my publisher closed its doors. And now? We’re back, and better than ever.

title: Commencement.
partialText: Tomorrow to fresh woods, and pastures new.

title: Parker.
partialText: Another year, another redesign. Might as well get to work.

title: Moving on from 18F.
partialText: I had a wonderful job, until I didn’t. This is about what happened—and what is still happening.

title: A challenge of blog questions.
partialText: Jon and Naz kindly tagged me into a blogging challenge! Namely, to answer a set of questions about how I blog, and why.

title: Ames & Amherst.
partialText: No hate. No fear—well, a fair bit of fear. But I’m ready.

title: Two books, no longer apart.
partialText: I’ve put my first two books online for free.

title: A catalog.
partialText: Here are some things I know.

title: Times to strike.
partialText: The largest union of tech workers just went on strike.

title: Reacquired.
partialText: Last year, I wrote a book. Several months later, my publisher closed its doors. This is about what happens next.

title: This site goes up to Eleventy.
partialText: I just migrated this little website’s internals over to Eleventy. If I did my job right, you won’t notice the change.

title: Hello, 18F.
partialText: I’ve been a designer at 18F for one week now.

title: Slingshot.
partialText: I just attended my first Labor Notes Conference. My head’s full, and my heart’s on fire.

title: Blockin’ bots.
partialText: Here’s how I’m blocking “artificial intelligence” bots, crawlers, and scrapers.

title: The negotiation cycle.
partialText: On the work, and being endlessly clever.

title: Lowe.
partialText: Spotted a copy of You Deserve a Tech Union at my local library. It made my decade.

title: Generative.
partialText: Nineteen thoughts about “generative artificial intelligence,” spanning a few centuries.

title: Collective.
partialText: A prominent investor got excited about collective bargaining. I did too! (But probably for different reasons.)

title: Reviewed.
partialText: My book was reviewed in Labor Notes. I’m still pinching myself.

title: The 2023 that was.
partialText: A little marker for myself, from one year to the next.

title: Broadly.
partialText: I’m excited to share a change in You Deserve a Tech Union’s pricing.

title: A new op-ed: on OpenAI and worker power.
partialText: What happens when workers take collective action, and in an anti-worker industry?

title: Boston meetup, redux: “You deserve a tech union!”
partialText: Tech workers of Boston! Curious about unions? We’re having another meetup about it!

title: Boston meetup: “Why do tech workers deserve a union?”
partialText: Tech workers of Boston! Curious about unions? Let’s have a meetup about it!

title: In medias.
partialText: Writin’ up—for you, but also for me—a few book events from last week.

title: Minetta.
partialText: I went to a conference last weekend, and it was wonderful. In fact, I’m still thinking about it—and about what can happen next.

title: A little book and its author, out in the world.
partialText: So! You Deserve a Tech Union’s been getting a little attention lately! Here’s a short roundup.

title: Three weeks.
partialText: You Deserve a Tech Union’s launch feels like it was just yesterday! What is time anymore

title: Labor’s day.
partialText: Some tech unions could use our support.

title: Mail, run.
partialText: What else happened this week? Well, I wrote my first op-ed; also, I got some mail.

title: You Deserve a Tech Union is here!
partialText: Well, hey! Happy pub day to my latest book!

title: Tick TOC.
partialText: Here’s the table of contents for You Deserve a Tech Union. (Also, hey: how about a sample chapter?)

title: Street team.
partialText: My new book, You Deserve a Tech Union, is almost here. Here’s how you can help support it!

title: Post by post.
partialText: Life after Twitter remains, well, weird. Maybe this is better.

title: Blurbs.
partialText: Blurbs are starting to come in for You Deserve a Tech Union, along with several emotions.

title: Announcing my new book, You Deserve a Tech Union.
partialText: I wrote this book for you, for me—for all of us. I hope you like it.

title: Bookin’.
partialText: Hey, this is neat: A Book Apart is available in bookstores, and around the world.

title: Tooled.
partialText: The work, and who gets to do it.

title: Adoption.
partialText: What we talk about when we talk about measuring a design system.

title: Notes from a dining room chair.
partialText: On getting stuck, and what you worry about when you worry about writing.

title: Truthish.
partialText: Whose sources, and whose truths?

title: Points, break.
partialText: When did we start using “breakpoint” to talk about layout adaptation? (Honestly, I don’t know!)

title: Notes from a dining room table.
partialText: For what comes next, whatever it is.

title: Weekend updates.
partialText: Various and sundry design tweaks! Writing bios is still terrible! Dark Mode 2: The Return of Dark Mode! It’s good to be back!

title: Parts, parcel.
partialText: At some point, something shifted.

title: À la porte.
partialText: I should probably check my email again.

title: Locus.
partialText: What’s better, where, and for whom.

title: Splits.
partialText: For now, I’ve got my feet under me. And I’m grateful.

title: Notes from a week.
partialText: Hello. It’s been a week. (A little more than, if I’m being honest.)

title: Stress systems.
partialText: On feeling overwhelmed by systems.

title: Bookiversary.
partialText: The fine folks at A Book Apart asked me to participate in a little interview, as my little yellow book just turned ten years old!

title: Responsive design and container queries? Oh my!
partialText: At long last, container queries might finally become reality! And responsive design just turned eleven! My goodness!

title: Union.
partialText: Tech workers, it’s time we unionize.

title: New work: Free design systems courses, available at Aquent Gymnasium.
partialText: I’ve launched four courses on design systems, available for free at Aquent Gymnasium! I hope you like them.

title: Design-ish systems.
partialText: “Why create a design system?” It’s a good question, if a hard one.

title: Au revoir, mon AMPmour?
partialText: Last year, Google announced AMP will no longer be a requirement for prime search placement. This is good! But I still have questions.

title: A day, typical.
partialText: Sara Soueidan asked how I typically spend my days. Here’s how I typically spend my days.

title: Beacon.
partialText: Looking for a few bright spots in everyone’s worst year.

title: My design systems reading list.
partialText: A friend asked me to share a few favorite resources on design systems. I thought I’d share them with you, too.

title: Before dawn, and after dusk.
partialText: I spoke at two events yesterday. I drank a lot of coffee. I talked a lot about design systems. Good day.

title: Speaking, remotely.
partialText: Here’s how I think about my speaking fee for remote events.

title: Hello, Autogram.
partialText: Karen and Jeff and I have launched a little strategic consultancy. We’re calling it Autogram, and I’d like to tell you why.

title: Replyin’.
partialText: I’ve added “Reply via email” links to my RSS feed. Hope you find it useful.

title: Notes from a hill.
partialText: She asked, “Are you looking forward to your birthday?”

title: The design systems between us.
partialText: It’s often suggested that design systems would improve the way organizations work. I’ve been wondering about that.

title: Takin’ five.
partialText: I’ve been lucky enough to work with Aquent Gymnasium on a series of short video tutorials. I hope you like them.

title: On context.
partialText: I read these two essays some time ago, and I keep returning to them. I bet you’ll like them too.

title: Power.
partialText: Individually, there’s little we can do; but collectively, there’s not much we can’t.

title: A programming note.
partialText: I’m pausing my email newsletter for a bit. More importantly, here are some organizations doing necessary work right now, and some resources I’ve found helpful.

title: Responsive design: seams & edges.
partialText: In some ways, responsive design was an attempt to move past the idea of a “page.” How’s that worked out for us?

title: Responsive web design turns ten.
partialText: The original “Responsive Web Design” article was published a decade ago! Here’s how it happened, and who helped make it happen.

title: An interview for the Responsive Web Design newsletter.
partialText: Justin Avery kindly invited me to do an interview for his wonderful Responsive Web Design newsletter. So you know I had to oblige.

title: Gardened.
partialText: On JavaScript, frameworks, and how giving a damn doesn’t scale.

title: Constrained CSS grids without max-width.
partialText: Stumbled across a little layout technique while working on my latest redesign. I think it’s helpful; maybe you’ll think so, too.

title: Writing my accessibility statement.
partialText: It was long overdue, but I’ve added an accessibility statement to my website. Here are a few reasons why.

title: Let a website be a worry stone.
partialText: One turn deserves another.

title: Through a design system, darkly.
partialText: Design systems haven’t solved the consistency problem—far from it. What can?

title: The design systems we swim in.
partialText: When was the last time a design system empowered you to make a decision? (I’m honestly asking.)

title: “With Great Tech Comes Great Responsibility.”
partialText: I liked Mozilla’s guide to student organizing and workplace ethics so much, I made a web page out of it.

title: The hoof and the horse.
partialText: On objects and slices; on design systems and scale.

title: Getting to work.
partialText: It’s time for us to organize our workplaces, my loves.

title: The World-Wide Work.
partialText: A talk on automation, power, justice, and labor in the tech industry.

title: Amphora.
partialText: I tried navigating some of Google’s featured AMP Stories in a screen reader. And then I wrote this.

title: Three bowls.
partialText: Saying good-bye to our littlest kitty, Rorschach.

title: Columbia & Elm; Fairfield & Gloucester.
partialText: Thinking about web accessibility, and getting from here to there.

title: Theorized.
partialText: I’ve been at Theorizing The Web for the last few days. I really liked it; I think you might, too.

title: Trainers.
partialText: How the data gets made, and by whom.

title: The web we broke.
partialText: I read something depressing last Monday, and I can’t stop thinking about it.

title: A reading list for “The World-Wide Work.”
partialText: I just gave a talk at this year’s New Adventures conference. Here are some books, resources, and videos I cited in it.

title: A new adventure.
partialText: I just got home from attending—and speaking at!—last week’s New Adventures conference. It was an inspiring, marvelous day.

title: Sonnerie.
partialText: I come not to praise 2018, but to bury it.

title: How I write conference talks.
partialText: I’m writing a new talk. This is how I do it.

title: Azeban.
partialText: Let’s talk a little about automation, design, and work.

title: Release.
partialText: I went to Demo Day for the latest Resilient Coders bootcamp. The students left an impression on me.

title: It’s not about the device.
partialText: It can feel overwhelming to design for a new device, a new context. Maybe there’s an alternative?

title: Syenite.
partialText: I’ve attended a few community sessions at Resilient Coders. It’s a wonderful organization; maybe you’d like to support them, too.

title: Vox pop.
partialText: I’m working with the team at Vox Media on their design systems. I’m very excited.

title: Designing, laws, and attitudes.
partialText: What would happen if the law required us to design fast websites?

title: The fundamentals of responsive design, now on Skillshare.
partialText: My new class, “Responsive Web Design: Creating Flexible Websites That Last”, is now live on Skillshare. I made it just for you.

title: The tool and the task.
partialText: Our design tools change the design of our products and, at times, they can change us. How do we talk about that?

title: Notes from a crosswalk.
partialText: On the route, the steps, and what follows.

title: My favorite design tool.
partialText: What if someone doesn’t browse the web like I do? Or like you do?

title: My foreword for Image Performance.
partialText: I was asked to write an introduction for Mat Marquis’ new book on images and performance, which I loved. (I think you’ll love it too.)

title: Revamp.
partialText: Google’s Accelerated Mobile Project (AMP) has announced it’s moving to a more open governance model, which is great. I still have some questions.

title: Accessibility is not a feature.
partialText: Lately, I’ve been reflecting on some of the language I use to talk about accessibility. It might be language you use, too.

title: An interview for Versioning.
partialText: I was recently invited to do a Q&A session for Sitepoint’s Versioning newsletter.

title: Izakaya.
partialText: When a dollar becomes ten.

title: Weft.
partialText: About the patterns underneath the patterns.

title: Bits.
partialText: What we talk about when we talk about what we talk about when we talk about web performance.

title: Notes from a market.
partialText: The sun was hot, the smiles were wide.

title: In the pocket.
partialText: “The first level of reality is that nitty-gritty stuff, the direct action and immediate experience, the sort of thing I like to call vernacular reality.” — Ursula Franklin

title: Chimpin’.
partialText: I use Mailchimp’s “RSS campaigns” to email new blog entries to subscribers. I also use responsive images. Here’s how I got them to play well together!

title: Fractional.
partialText: The more I work with CSS Grid, the more I’ve realized I’m a big fan of the fr unit. And it’s subtly changed how I think about grids.

title: Just work.
partialText: How I work, and how I want to.

title: My three steps.
partialText: I’ve been thinking about how I learn new technologies.

title: World wide wrist.
partialText: WebKit’s coming to the Apple Watch, in some fashion. In my own fashion, I’m excited to see what that means.

title: Bundt.
partialText: Here’s what happened today, today.

title: A GIFt—or three!—from me, to thee.
partialText: I have a website called bukk.it. It’s filled with pointless images. Here’s how I manage it.

title: Kumiho.
partialText: Thoughts on bots.

title: When patterns get weird.
partialText: Usually, you’ll get rid of design patterns that don’t contribute much to your design system. But sometimes, you won’t.

title: What’s in a pattern name?
partialText: The benefit of creating a pattern library isn’t the patterns as such.

title: Notes from a conference.
partialText: I just flew in from Florida, where I’d spoken—and workshopped!—at the 2018 Front End Design Conference. And boy, are my arms tired/sunburnt.

title: Spinning jenny.
partialText: A few thoughts on the task, and the tool.

title: Framed.
partialText: When offering advice, be careful how it’s offered.

title: The podcast is dead; long live the podcast!
partialText: This was the vehicle; these were the people.

title: Campaign.
partialText: The Google AMP team has announced they’d like to make the web faster—even for folks who don’t use AMP. That’s wonderful news. But I have some questions.

title: Notes from a sidewalk.
partialText: She stood back up, running to catch her friends, her sign held high.

title: I, for one.
partialText: We’re used to corporations stepping in to fix the problems they see on the web. But what would happen if we could fix the web?

title: Design, system.
partialText: Your design system’s more than the sum of its patterns. (It’s all about the people, maaaaannnn.)

title: Stupid Jekyll tricks.
partialText: Right now, my site runs on Jekyll. Here are two little things I find useful.

title: AMPlified.
partialText: I don’t think there’s much you or I can do about Google’s AMP project. However.

title: A little advice.
partialText: On occasion, people starting a career in web design ask me for advice. Here’s what I currently say to them.

title: Cardigan.
partialText: Farewell, Dean. And thank you.

title: War rig.
partialText: I come here not to praise 2017, but to bury it.

title: Rated zero.
partialText: Google AMP, and services like it, are a kind of “zero-rating.” I worry about that.

title: Entitled to.
partialText: A few thoughts about losing net neutrality protections in the United States, and what happens next.

title: A new bag.
partialText: On a friend’s recommendation, I bought a Tom Bihn backpack for traveling. I really like it.

title: In range.
partialText: Three outlines, each smaller than the last.

title: Seven into seven.
partialText: A few more thoughts on AMP, on Ursula Franklin’s questions, and on just technology.

title: My foreword for Design Systems.
partialText: I was asked to write an introduction for Alla Kholmatova’s new book on design systems, which I loved. (I think you’ll love it too.)

title: AMPersand.
partialText: There’s a price to using Google’s “Accelerated Mobile Project.” I’m not sure the web can afford to pay it.

title: At dawn.
partialText: Waking up, half-dreaming, before the sun’s up.

title: Upward and worn.
partialText: The new Legend of Zelda is a gorgeous, fun game, but it’s also an isolation simulator. And I love that about it.

title: Designed lines.
partialText: Designing a lightweight, inexpensive digital experience is a form of kindness.

title: A responsive spotlight.
partialText: We’ve been trying something new on our little responsive design podcast. I’ve enjoyed the experiment; maybe you will, too.

title: A working pattern library.
partialText: The value of a pattern library is tied directly to how much—and how easily—it is used.

title: Left to our own devices.
partialText: For me, the real value of a device lab isn’t in testing. A device lab is a design tool.

title: Notes from a chair.
partialText: They work kindly, quickly but steadily, under lights cold and bright.

title: Going offline.
partialText: I’ve started taking parts of my site offline. Here’s how it works, right now.

title: Device intervention.
partialText: Done right, a device lab’s a pretty good empathy engine.

title: The work I like.
partialText: I’ve been thinking a lot about why I work the way I do, and how.

title: MOA—
partialText: And yet.

title: A bit more on container queries.
partialText: Paul Robert Lloyd persuasively argues that container queries are obsolete. I respectfully disagree.

title: A sticky situation.
partialText: Ran into a little design bug, involving position: sticky and Chrome. Maybe it’d be of interest to you.

title: The bricks we lay.
partialText: Design is not neutral.

title: Notes from a couch.
partialText: I’ve got a week of rest lined up, so here’s what I’m reading and watching. (Riveting stuff, I know.)

title: On container queries.
partialText: A number of prominent web folks have been asking for “container queries.” I think they’re right to do so, and here’s why.

title: New work: Source
partialText: A new design for Source, a non-profit that makes journalism code more visible.

title: Notes from a protest.
partialText: No hate. No fear.

title: Free, faster.
partialText: Many of the free web themes I’ve seen recently are…slow. How can we fix that?

title: The good by.
partialText: A few notes on farewells, and on coming home.

title: Pattern patter.
partialText: On the web, can our patterns be more than just front-end code?

title: Hyper text.
partialText: A few notes on political anxiety and Twitter, and how sentences turn into paragraphs.

title: Thread.
partialText: Welcome to my new website.

title: Announcing my new book, Responsive Design: Patterns and Principles.
partialText: I’ve written a new book! It’s about moving beyond the page, and designing with patterns. I hope you like it.

title: My questions for event organizers.
partialText: When I’m asked to speak at an event, I ask a few useful questions. Maybe you’ll find them useful, too.

title: The second edition of Responsive Web Design.
partialText: There’s a second edition of my book! It’s still about responsive design, but quite a bit has changed.

title: A Responsive Design Podcast.
partialText: Along with Karen McGrane, I’m getting into that “pod-casting” game! (Guess what it’s about.)

title: Platformed.
partialText: The web isn’t a platform. When we design and build for it, we should remember that.

title: So you’re interested in a responsive design workshop…
partialText: Karen McGrane and I have teamed up to offer in-house workshops on—you guessed it!—responsive design. Hire us!

title: Speaking? Pack a plan.
partialText: If you’re doing any public speaking, I have a few small (but useful!) tips.

title: “The second step is inclusiveness.”
partialText: Here’s a quote on inclusive design I quite liked. (Maybe you’ll like it, too.)

title: Keynote, Magic Move, and you.
partialText: One of my favorite features in Apple’s Keynote is “Magic Move.” I bet it might be yours, too.

title: “Offline First”
partialText: I’m so excited about building more offline-friendly experiences. (You should be, too!)

title: Responsive design, screens, and shearing layers.
partialText: Responsive design might begin with the screen, but it doesn’t end there.

title: Hello, Editorially.
partialText: I’ve cofounded a startup with some dear friends. It’s called Editorially. I’d like to tell you a little about it.

title: The Boston Globe
partialText: The first large-scale responsive website just launched, and I helped. Here’s how we did it.

title: So I wrote a book. It’s called Responsive Web Design.
partialText: Want to learn responsive design? There’s a book for that. (And I wrote it!)

title: Henry.
partialText: A few words I quite like.

title: Toffee-nosed.
partialText: Many criticisms of responsive design are based on faulty logic. Let’s look at a few fallacies.

title: With good references.
partialText: Every responsive design begins with a reference layout, either small- or widescreen. Which should you choose?

title: On being “responsive.”
partialText: What makes a responsive design “responsive,” anyway?

title: Oversewing
partialText: I’ve moved on from working at Happy Cog, and I’ve started up my own design practice again.

title: On fluid grids.
partialText: I have a new article on A List Apart. It’s about creating complex grid-based layouts that are fluid. I hope you like it.

title: Bradley.
partialText: A story about my late uncle, who I didn’t know as well as I wish I did.

title: Squee.
partialText: I’ve written my first article for A List Apart. I’m so excited.

title: Day zero.
partialText: Last Friday was my last day at a full-time job.

title: Stairwell.
partialText: Starting a new job.

title: On emergency rooms.
partialText: We were in the process of haggling over which desserts my grandmother should order when the seizure hit.

title: In progress
partialText: A former teacher and his former student, and a house to paint.

title: She.
partialText: Happy anniversary, to my one and lovely.
